SOUND:
THE NOISES OF THE STREET
CRIER:
Here’s your fine ripe water=melonsJ Here's your fine ripe water-
melonsS (FADE OFF CALLING)
TOC:
Listen, Beaumont! Listen to the street criers. Everywhere we are
pursued by this wild enthusiasm for trade.
BEAU:
There are also street-criers in France,
TOC:
But these street criers are different. They have meanings They belong
to a pattern.
SWEEP:
Sweep all up 3 Sweep all up3 from the bottom to the top, without a
ladder or a rope, sweep 0-0-0-03 (FADE OFF CALLING)
BEAU:
You are eyeing that chimney sweep as if he were a future millionaire of
the new democracy«
TOC:
Who knows? Perhaps he may be 3
BEAU:
The Governors ideas have excited youS
TOC:
Of course. All ideas are exciting; and what we are seeing, Beaumont,
is a new world unfolding.
OLD LABI:
Cat tails? Cat tails to make beds going? Cat tails? Cat tails to
make beds going? (FADE OFF CALLING)
BEAU:
This woman; is she too a future millionaire?
TOC:
Now you make fun; but I must write down that Americans sometimes sleep
on the tails of cats.
BEAU:
Look at the people, Toeqaeville, as well as the ideas? She is selling
reeds, rushes, bulrushes.
TOC:
Fy eyes are opened; indeed, they really are. See, across the side¬
walk in front of every shop, a long board nailed across two posts with
advertising painted on it, I never noticed that as we came up the
street; but now everywhere I look I see evidences ox trades ”Visit
